headline.main: ONLY BIG CIRCUS LEFT ON ROAD NETS PROFIT; Barnes-Sells-Floto 'Out of Red' and Will Continue Tour

docs.snippet: The day. "only major circus on the road" since the "Greatest Show on Earth" closed has shown a profit and will continue its tour, John Ringling North decided....
docs.lead_paragraph: The day. "only major circus on the road" since the "Greatest Show on Earth" closed has shown a profit and will continue its tour, John Ringling North decided.

headline.main: Lucky Bumpkin; THE GLADIATOR. By Thames Williamson. 344 pp. New York: Coward-McCann. $3.

docs.snippet: THE most recent historical fictionist to mount the Appian Way is Thames Williamson, who turns his talents to the time of Nero and the bloodiest gladitorial contests ever given a howling circus. His hero (a combination of his inarticulate giant, Je...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE most recent historical fictionist to mount the Appian Way is Thames Williamson, who turns his talents to the time of Nero and the bloodiest gladitorial contests ever given a howling circus. His hero (a combination of his inarticulate giant, Jencic in "Hunky" and the ambitious Daniel Patterson of "Stride of Man") is Faljan the drover.

docs.snippet: A gladiator seeks revenge for the murder of his family by the Emperor's son....
docs.lead_paragraph: A gladiator seeks revenge for the murder of his family by the Emperor's son.

docs.abstract: Gary Fox letter disputes Herbert Muschamp's April 30 article on movie Gladiator
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Good try, but you'll have to make some adjustments in the creative writing software (CWS) used to write the article ''Throwing Our Anxieties to the Lions'' [April 30]. I know that major advances have been made in using computers ...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Good try, but you'll have to make some adjustments in the creative writing software (CWS) used to write the article ''Throwing Our Anxieties to the Lions'' [April 30]. I know that major advances have been made in using computers to play chess and to simulate creative writing, but your system still has some major bugs.

docs.abstract: Gladiator-at-Law: by F Pohl, C M Kornbluth
docs.snippet: THE world-of-tomorrow envisioned by these two authors is a strange and frightening one, the more so because its seeds can be seen in today's society. Charles Mundin, a young lawyer whose practice and future are limited because he has not been born...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE world-of-tomorrow envisioned by these two authors is a strange and frightening one, the more so because its seeds can be seen in today's society. Charles Mundin, a young lawyer whose practice and future are limited because he has not been born into one of the great hereditary legal families, faces a world in which cruelty is commonplace.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Chief Sax Man Gets an Award SENATOR CHARLES E. SCHUMER unhooked the velvet rope from the brass stanchion and walked right up to the power table where his soon-to-be colleague, SENATOR-ELECT HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON, was having dinner with PRESIDENT CLINTON, ROBERT DE NIRO, QUEEN NOOR of Jordan, GOLDIE HAWN and KURT RUSSELL.

docs.abstract: Profile of Joaquin Phoenix, nominated as best supporting actor for his role in Gladiator; photo (M) (Special supplement on the Oscars)

headline.main: In a Restless Family Of Talent and Tragedy, Another Star Is Born

docs.snippet: IT is one hour after Joaquin Phoenix is scheduled to arrive at The Algonquin hotel in Manhattan and there is no sign of him. The doormen are asked to be on the lookout while his handlers frantically try to track him down. This could mean trouble. ...
docs.lead_paragraph: IT is one hour after Joaquin Phoenix is scheduled to arrive at The Algonquin hotel in Manhattan and there is no sign of him. The doormen are asked to be on the lookout while his handlers frantically try to track him down. This could mean trouble. After all, Mr. Phoenix has gotten almost as much buzz for his two bizarre appearances on late-night talk shows last year, in which he rambled incoherently at times, as he has for his Oscar nomination for playing a corrupt emperor's son in ''The Gladiator.'' One magazine went as far as to wonder, ''Is Joaquin Phoenix the new Farrah Fawcett or what?'' The answer would seem to be no. Mr. Phoenix is finally located, 25 blocks uptown at Armani, getting fitted for the tuxedo he will wear to the Academy Awards ceremony on March 25. He could not be more apologetic as he calls, sounding quite lucid, on his cell phone, and races downtown for the interview. For this child of hippies, the third of five siblings who moved with his family 40 times in 20 years, the duties and obligations that come with an Oscar nomination are apparently a bit overwhelming. As a result, he lost track of time.

docs.abstract: Gary Friedman letter calls Herbert Muschamp's April 30 article on movie Gladiator psychobabble
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Did I hear this right? Young Butch, growing up abnormally normal in that worst of all worlds, the postwar suburbs, saves himself by choosing to turn queer as he prepares to become a serial killer, while Dad makes gyroscopes to co...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Did I hear this right? Young Butch, growing up abnormally normal in that worst of all worlds, the postwar suburbs, saves himself by choosing to turn queer as he prepares to become a serial killer, while Dad makes gyroscopes to commit atrocities overseas and Mom is rushed off to a hushed-up stay at a rest home.

docs.snippet: When an actor commits himself to a role as fully as Russell Crowe does in the grandiose and silly ''Gladiator,'' you may ask yourself why and at the same time thank him for his absorption in the part.    No one has tried a revisionist take on the ...
docs.lead_paragraph: When an actor commits himself to a role as fully as Russell Crowe does in the grandiose and silly ''Gladiator,'' you may ask yourself why and at the same time thank him for his absorption in the part. No one has tried a revisionist take on the gnashing-teeth, sweaty-torso, clanging-steel epic since Arnold Schwarzenegger crushed all the consonants under his sandaled feet in ''Conan the Barbarian'' almost 20 years ago. The story of a proud Roman soldier who is sold into slavery and must fight his way back to freedom, ''Gladiator'' suggests what would happen if someone made a movie of the imminent extreme-football league and shot it as if it were a Chanel commercial.
